what: Prepare a definition matrix for analysis which indicates which samples are cases and controls.
title: CIBRA impact score for a genomic alteration
text: example focus 6 genes: tumor suppressor genes APC TP53, oncogenes KRAS, BRAF PIK3CA often mutated gene TTN colorectal cancer.
code: # prepare data for CIBRA  # select genes of interest goi <- c("APC", "TP53", "KRAS", "BRAF", "PIK3CA", "TTN", "MACROD2")  # filter mutation profile for only selected genes definition_matrix <- mutation_profile[goi]  # fix sample names for intersect between the two datatypes rownames(definition_matrix) <- stringr::str_replace_all(rownames(definition_matrix), "-", ".")  # select intersect between definition matrix and count data sample_list <- intersect(rownames(definition_matrix), colnames(count_data))  # select data and definition matrix as the intersect count_data <- count_data[sample_list] definition_matrix <- definition_matrix[sample_list,]  # optional to visualize datafrane if (!require("DT")) install.packages('DT') DT::datatable(definition_matrix)

what: Set the parameters to use with CIBRA and run CIBRA.
title: CIBRA impact score for a genomic alteration
text: can provide larger definition matrix indicate columns test CIBRA. number permutation iterations perform recommended 50 give indication intrinsic variation dataset given size cases control. However make example run quicker set 0 turns internal permutation. results reported tested definition (def), SNVs case, column assessed (col) gene assessed. proportion significant area (sign_area) impact measures reported. number cases (investigated) controls reported. Moreover, iterations set 0, average permutation signal measures standard deviation reported.
code: # focus on APC columns <- c("APC")  # set up parameters for CIBRA control_definition <- "WT" # reference condition confidence <- 0.1 # confidence threshold for the proportion calculation # set permutation to 0 to skip permutations iterations = 0 # number of permutation iterations to be performed per condition  register(SnowParam(4)) # set number of cores to be used  # run CIBRA with default DE analysis method (DESeq2) CIBRA_res <- run_CIBRA(count_data, as.data.frame(definition_matrix),                         columns = columns,                         control_definition = control_definition,                         confidence = confidence,                         iterations = iterations,                         parallel = TRUE) #> [1] "SNV" #> [1] "APC" "SNV" # print the report table knitr::kable(CIBRA_res$CIBRA_results, format = "html")

what: Assess significance of the signal measures
title: CIBRA impact score for a genomic alteration
text: performing permutation test gamma fitted estimate, additional columns p-values added results. “perm_test_prop” “perm_test_sign_area” p-values generated standard permutation test given permutation distribution provided. “pvalue_prop” “pvalue_sign_area” pvalues generated fitted Gamma distribution.
code: # calculate the pvalue by comparing to a reference distribution generated with DESeq2 perm_data <- CIBRA::perm_dist_crc_tcga  # use the gamma test to also calculate a fitted p-value CIBRA_res_stat <-  permutation_test(CIBRA_res$CIBRA_results, perm_data, test = "gamma")  # print the report table knitr::kable(CIBRA_res_stat$results, format = "html")

title: CIBRA impact score for a genomic alteration
text: default DE method used CIBRA DESeq2. However, edgeR Limma-Voom also supported.
code: # run CIBRA with Limma-Voom CIBRA_limma_voom <- run_CIBRA(count_data, as.data.frame(definition_matrix),                                columns = columns,                               control_definition = control_definition,                                confidence = confidence,                                iterations = iterations,                                parallel = TRUE, method = "limma") #> [1] "SNV" #> [1] "APC" "SNV"  # print the report table knitr::kable(CIBRA_limma_voom$CIBRA_results, format = "html") # run CIBRA with EdgeR CIBRA_edger <- run_CIBRA(count_data, as.data.frame(definition_matrix),                                columns = columns,                               control_definition = control_definition,                                confidence = confidence,                                iterations = iterations,                                parallel = TRUE, method = "edger") #> [1] "SNV" #> [1] "APC" "SNV"  # print the report table knitr::kable(CIBRA_edger$CIBRA_results, format = "html")

title: Authors and Citation
text: Soufyan Lakbir. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lakbir S, Buranelli C, Meijer GA, Heringa J, Fijneman RJA, Abeln S (2024). “CIBRA identifies genomic alterations system-wide impact tumor biology.” Bioinformatics. doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btae384, https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btae384.
code: @Article{,   title = {CIBRA identifies genomic alterations with a system-wide impact on tumor biology},   author = {Soufyan Lakbir and Caterina Buranelli and Gerrit A. Meijer and Jaap Heringa and Remond J. A. Fijneman and Sanne Abeln},   doi = {10.1093/bioinformatics/btae384},   journal = {Bioinformatics},   year = {2024},   month = {September},   url = {https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btae384}, }

title: CIBRA: Computational Identification of Biologically Relevant Alterations
text: can install development version CIBRA GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("AIT4LIFE-UU/CIBRA")

title: CIBRA: Computational Identification of Biologically Relevant Alterations
text: extensive examples utility CIBRA, please consult vignettes.
code: # load functions library(CIBRA) library(BiocParallel)  # load transcription data and genomic alterations from TCGA COADREAD count_data <- CIBRA::TCGA_CRC_rna_data mutation_profile <- CIBRA::TCGA_CRC_non_silent_mutation_profile

what: Prepare a definition matrix for analysis which indicates which samples are cases and controls.
title: CIBRA: Computational Identification of Biologically Relevant Alterations
text: example focus 6 genes: tumor suppressor genes APC TP53, oncogenes KRAS, BRAF PIK3CA often mutated gene TTN colorectal cancer.
code: # prepare data for CIBRA  # select genes of interest goi <- c("APC", "TP53", "KRAS", "BRAF", "PIK3CA")  # filter mutation profile for only selected genes definition_matrix <- mutation_profile[goi]  # fix sample names for intersect between the two datatypes rownames(definition_matrix) <- stringr::str_replace_all(rownames(definition_matrix), "-", ".")  # select intersect between definition matrix and count data sample_list <- intersect(rownames(definition_matrix), colnames(count_data))  # select data and definition matrix as the intersect count_data <- count_data[sample_list] definition_matrix <- definition_matrix[sample_list,]  # show definition matrix knitr::kable(head(definition_matrix))

what: Set the parameters to use with CIBRA and run CIBRA.
title: CIBRA: Computational Identification of Biologically Relevant Alterations
text: can provide larger definition matrix indicate columns test CIBRA. number permutation iterations perform recommended 50 give indication intrinsic variation dataset given size cases control. However make example run quicker set 0 turns internal permutation. iterations set 0, average permutation signal measures standard deviation reported.
code: # focus on APC columns <- goi  # set up parameters for CIBRA control_definition <- "WT" # reference condition confidence <- 0.1 # confidence threshold for the proportion calculation # set permutation to 0 to skip permutations iterations = 0 # number of permutation iterations to be performed per condition  register(SnowParam(4)) # set number of cores to be used  # run CIBRA with default DE analysis method (DESeq2) CIBRA_res <- run_CIBRA(count_data, as.data.frame(definition_matrix),                         columns = columns,                         control_definition = control_definition,                         confidence = confidence,                         iterations = iterations,                         parallel = TRUE) #> [1] "SNV" #> [1] "APC" "SNV" #> [1] "SNV" #> [1] "TP53" "SNV"  #> [1] "SNV" #> [1] "KRAS" "SNV"  #> [1] "SNV" #> [1] "BRAF" "SNV"  #> [1] "SNV" #> [1] "PIK3CA" "SNV" # print the report table knitr::kable(CIBRA_res$CIBRA_results)

what: Assess significance of the signal measures
title: CIBRA: Computational Identification of Biologically Relevant Alterations
code: # calculate the pvalue by comparing to a reference distribution generated with DESeq2 perm_data <- CIBRA::perm_dist_crc_tcga  # use the gamma test to also calculate a fitted p-value CIBRA_res_stat <-  permutation_test(CIBRA_res$CIBRA_results, perm_data, test = "gamma")  # print the report table knitr::kable(CIBRA_res_stat$results)

title: CIBRA: Computational Identification of Biologically Relevant Alterations
code: require(ggplot2) require(dplyr) require(scales)  # visualize the results plot_data <- CIBRA_res_stat$results %>% select(col, investigated, control, sign_area,                                   pvalue_sign_area)  p <- ggplot(plot_data, aes(y = as.numeric(sign_area),                            x = factor(col), fill = pvalue_sign_area)) +    geom_point(aes(size = as.numeric(investigated)/(as.numeric(investigated)                                                    + as.numeric(control))*100),               shape = 21,               color = "black", stroke = 1.5) +   ylab("CIBRA impact score (Significant Area)") + xlab("") +    scale_fill_continuous('p-value', low = "#ffffcc", high = "#800026",                          breaks = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05, 0.25, 1),                         trans = compose_trans("log10", "reverse"),                         limits = c(1,0.00001)) +   scale_size_area(name = "Cases (%)",                    breaks = c(25, 50, 75, 100),                   limit = c(0,100), max_size = 8) +   ylim(c(0,0.5)) +   theme_minimal() +   guides(size = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE, override.aes=list(fill = "darkgrey")))  print(p)

title: CIBRA: Computational Identification of Biologically Relevant Alterations
text: questions, suggestions, bug reports, please send e-mail Soufyan Lakbir (s.lakbir@vu.nl). use CIBRA published research, please cite: Lakbir S, et al. CIBRA identifies genomic alterations system-wide impact tumor biology. Bioinformatics. 2024 Sep 1;40(Suppl 2):ii37-ii44. doi: 10.1093/bioinformatics/btae384. PMID: 39230704; PMCID: PMC11373315.

title: Generate CIBRA impact score permutation distribution — generate_permutation_dist
code: generate_permutation_dist(   data,   case_list,   control_list,   control_definition,   confidence,   iterations,   covariates = c(),   covariate_matrix = NULL,   parallel = FALSE,   method = "DESeq2",   permutation = "full" )

title: Generate CIBRA impact score permutation distribution — generate_permutation_dist
text: data RNA count dataframe genes rows samples columns case_list vector number cases test (vector) control_list vector number controls test (vector) control_definition Definition term used reference comparison (e.g. WT) confidence alpha threshold calculate proportion (default 0.1) iterations number interations (int) covariates list column names definition matrix use covariates (supported DESeq2) covariate_matrix design dataframe covariates, columns take along covariate values samples rownames. parallel boolean status run done parallel (boolean) method method perform differential expression analysis, supported methods DESeq2, edgeR limma permutation permutation style perform, either full values matrix permuted sample samples permuted.

title: Generate CIBRA impact score permutation distribution — generate_permutation_dist
text: list permutation results (dataframe), p-value, adjusted p-value foldchange generated DE analysis permutations

title: Generate CIBRA impact score permutation distribution — generate_permutation_dist
code: # load transcriptomics data count_data <- CIBRA::TCGA_CRC_rna_data  # subset sample to have a quicker run-time for the example count_data <- count_data[,1:50]  # set parameters for the reference distribution control_definition <- "NO_SNV" confidence <- 0.1 # use the same confidence as used in standard analysis iterations <- 9 # recommended are at least 1000 permutations to explore the full space  # create lists of different case and control sizes case_list <- seq(10, ncol(count_data), length.out = 3) # recommended value is at least 20 different case and control values control_list <- seq(10, ncol(count_data), length.out = 3)  # run permutation screen CIBRA_res <- generate_permutation_dist(data = count_data, case_list = case_list, control_list = control_list, control_definition = control_definition, confidence = confidence, iterations = iterations, parallel = FALSE, permutation = "sample") #> [1] "testing: 10and 10" #> [1] "cases: 10, controls: 10, iteration: 1" #> estimating size factors #> estimating dispersions #> gene-wise dispersion estimates #> mean-dispersion relationship #> final dispersion estimates #> fitting model and testing #> -- replacing outliers and refitting for 3316 genes #> -- DESeq argument 'minReplicatesForReplace' = 7  #> -- original counts are preserved in counts(dds) #> estimating dispersions #> fitting model and testing #> [1] "cases: 10, controls: 10, iteration: 2" #> estimating size factors #> estimating dispersions #> gene-wise dispersion estimates #> mean-dispersion relationship #> final dispersion estimates #> fitting model and testing #> -- replacing outliers and refitting for 1598 genes #> -- DESeq argument 'minReplicatesForReplace' = 7  #> -- original counts are preserved in counts(dds) #> estimating dispersions #> fitting model and testing #> [1] "cases: 10, controls: 10, iteration: 3" #> estimating size factors #> estimating dispersions #> gene-wise dispersion estimates #> mean-dispersion relationship #> final dispersion estimates #> fitting model and testing #> -- replacing outliers and refitting for 2953 genes #> -- DESeq argument 'minReplicatesForReplace' = 7  #> -- original counts are preserved in counts(dds) #> estimating dispersions #> fitting model and testing #> [1] "Done with cases: 10, controls: 10" #> [1] "testing: 30and 10" #> [1] "cases: 30, controls: 10, iteration: 1" #> estimating what: Computationally identify biologically relevant alterations — run_CIBRA
title: Computationally identify biologically relevant alterations — run_CIBRA
text: run_CIBRA calculates impact score provided expression data defined definitions

title: Computationally identify biologically relevant alterations — run_CIBRA
code: run_CIBRA(   data,   definition_matrix,   columns,   control_definition,   confidence = 0.1,   iterations = 0,   covariates = c(),   method = "DESeq2",   parallel = FALSE,   speedup = FALSE,   min_n = 10,   outputDir = FALSE,   sample_column = NULL )

title: Computationally identify biologically relevant alterations — run_CIBRA
text: data RNA count dataframe genes rows samples columns definition_matrix design dataframe comparisons make, binary columns (factors) indication groups test samples rownames. columns columns definition_matrix assess respect control definition control_definition Definition term used reference comparison (e.g. WT) confidence alpha threshold calculate proportion (default 0.1) iterations number iterations random permutation (recommendation 50 iterations per definition) covariates list column names definition matrix use covariates (supported DESeq2) method method use differential expression analysis. options: 'DESeq2', 'edgeR' 'limma'. Defaults 'DESeq2' parallel boolean state operate parallel mode. Defaults FALSE speedup boolean state run DESeq2 speedup mode. Defaults FALSE min_n minimal number samples consider analysis. Defaults recommended minimum number samples: 10 outputDir path result files, FALSE, results written. Defaults FALSE sample_column name column containing sample names, NULL, rownames used

title: Computationally identify biologically relevant alterations — run_CIBRA
text: returns list containing dataframe signal measures associated metadata associated results generated differential expression analysis

title: Computationally identify biologically relevant alterations — run_CIBRA
code: require(dplyr) #> Loading required package: dplyr #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  # load transcription data and genomic alterations count_data <- CIBRA::TCGA_CRC_rna_data mutation_profile <- CIBRA::TCGA_CRC_non_silent_mutation_profile  # select BRAF as example goi <- c("BRAF", "APC", "TP53")  # filter mutation profile for only selected genes definition_matrix <- mutation_profile[goi]  # select only 30 samples for the cases (BRAF mutant) and controls (BRAF WT) for the sake of speed of the example # you can remove this limit if you want to run the full comparison  definition_matrix <- definition_matrix %>% tibble::rownames_to_column('sample') %>% group_by(BRAF) %>% sample_n(30) %>% tibble::column_to_rownames('sample')  #' # fix sample names for intersect between the two datatypes rownames(definition_matrix) <- stringr::str_replace_all(rownames(definition_matrix), "-", ".")  # select intersect between definition matrix and count data sample_list <- intersect(rownames(definition_matrix), colnames(count_data))  # select data and definition matrix as the intersect count_data <- count_data[sample_list] definition_matrix <- definition_matrix[sample_list,]  # select BRAF columns <- c("BRAF") # if more column were provided in the definition_matrix  # set up parameters for CIBRA control_definition <- "WT" # reference condition  confidence <- 0.1 # confidence threshold for the proportion calculation  # set permutation to 0 to skip permutations  iterations = 0 # number of permutation iterations to be performed per condition  # register(SnowParam(2)) # set number of cores to be used for parallel processing  # run CIBRA with default DE analysis method (DESeq2)  CIBRA_res <- run_CIBRA(count_data, as.data.frame(definition_matrix), columns = columns, control_definition = control_definition, confidence = confidence, iterations = iterations, parallel = FALSE) # set parallel to TRUE for parallel processing #> [1] "SNV" #> [1] "BRAF" "SNV"  #> estimating size factors #> estimating dispersions #> gene-wise dispersion estimates #> mean-dispersion relationship #> final dispersion estimates #> fitting model and testing #> -- replacing outliers and refitting for 2735 genes #> -- DESeq argument 'minReplicatesForReplace' = 7  #> -- original counts are preserved in counts(dds) #> estimating dispersions #> fitting model and testing  # calculate the pvalue by comparing to a reference distribution generated with DESeq2 perm_data <- CIBRA::perm_dist_crc_tcga  # use the gamma test to also calculate a fitted p-value CIBRA_res_stat <-  permutation_test(CIBRA_res$CIBRA_results, perm_data, test = "gamma")

title: CIBRA similarity score — similarity_measures
text: data1 dataframe columns pval (-log10 transformed adjusted pvalues DE analysis), fc (foldchange DE analysis) type indicating condition name. data2 data1 second condition plotDir directory path figures generated cond1 name condition 1 used figures cond2 name condition 2 used figures abs_perm_dist absolute permutation distribution distance score generated shown vignette xxx perm_dplus dplus permutation distribution generated shown vignette "CIBRA similarity score" perm_dmin dmin permutation distribution generated shown vignette "CIBRA similarity score" perm_mode Boolean indicate similarity_measures calculated permutation distribution. mode, figures generated. data1 data2 needed input mode

title: CIBRA similarity score — similarity_measures
text: Returns list containing calculated spearman correlation (rho), similarity score (dplus), anti-similarity score (dmin), genes associated similarity score (dplus_genes) genes associated anti-similarity score (dmin_genes). also generates figures

title: CIBRA similarity score — similarity_measures
code: # generate permutation similarity measures from the permutation distribution generated for the CIBRA impact score permutation_adj_pvalue <- CIBRA::permutation_adj_pvalue permutation_foldchange <- CIBRA::permutation_foldchange  # transform the pvalues trans_pvalues <- -log10(permutation_adj_pvalue)  rho_list <- c() Dplus_list <- c() Dmin_list <- c()  # generate 100 permutation similarity scores (recommended to atleast do 1000 permutations) for (i in 1:100) { # sample colnames to compare two random samples col.sets <- sample(colnames(permutation_foldchange),1) col2.sets <- sample(colnames(permutation_foldchange), 1)  # prepare data for diss score calculation data1 <- data.frame(genes = rownames(permutation_foldchange), pval = trans_pvalues[[col.sets]], fc = permutation_foldchange[[col.sets]], type = col.sets) data2 <- data.frame(genes = rownames(permutation_foldchange), pval = trans_pvalues[[col2.sets]], fc = permutation_foldchange[[col2.sets]], type = col2.sets) # similarity score scale_d = similarity_measures(data1, data2, perm_mode = TRUE) Dplus_list <- c(Dplus_list, scale_d$dplus) Dmin_list <- c(Dmin_list, scale_d$dmin) rho_list <- c(rho_list, scale_d$rho) } #> Warning: Setting row names on a tibble is deprecated. #> Warning: Setting row names on a tibble is deprecated. #> Warning: Setting row names on a tibble is deprecated. #> Warning: Setting row names on a tibble is deprecated. #> Warning: Setting row names on a tibble is deprecated.  # read pvalue and fc data for gene of interest (APC exons in this example) pvalues <- CIBRA::APC_definition_padj_values fc <- CIBRA::APC_definition_foldchange trans_pvalues <- -log10(pvalues)  # set variables for the permutation distributions perm_dist <- rho_list perm_dplus <- Dplus_list perm_dmin <- Dmin_list  # one sided test for the correlation measure abs_perm_dist <- abs(perm_dist) abs_perm_dist <- abs_perm_dist[!is.na(abs_perm_dist)]  # select data of the exons of interest, in this example exon 7 and 16 will be compared APC_exon_16 <- data.frame(genes = rownames(fc), pval = trans_pvalues$Transcript.APC.201_X16, fc = fc$Transcript.APC.201_X16, type = "APC exon 16") APC_exon_7 <- data.frame(genes = rownames(fc), pval = trans_pvalues$Transcript.APC.201_X7, fc = fc$Transcript.APC.201_X7, type = "APC exon 7")  apc_res <- similarity_measures(data1 = APC_exon_7, data2 = APC_exon_16, cond1 = stringr::str_replace_all(unique(APC_exon_7$type), " ", "_"), cond2 = stringr::str_replace_all(unique(APC_exon_16$type), " ", "_"), abs_perm_dist = abs_perm_dist, perm_dplus =  perm_dplus, perm_dmin = perm_dmin) #> Warning: Setting row names on a tibble is deprecated. #> Warning: Setting row names on a tibble is deprecated. #> Warning: The input is a data
